skill.description: Molecular featurization for ML (100+ featurizers). ECFP, MACCS, descriptors, pretrained models (ChemBERTa), convert SMILES to features, for QSAR and molecular ML.

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown files. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or file system access. This skill provides documentation and usage examples for the molfeat Python library.

content.value_statement: Transform chemical structures into numerical representations for machine learning. Supports 100+ featurizers including fingerprints, descriptors, and transformer models for QSAR modeling and drug discovery.
actual_capabilities: Convert SMILES strings to numerical feature vectors
Compute molecular fingerprints (ECFP, MACCS, MAP4, Avalon)
Apply pretrained transformer models (ChemBERTa, ChemGPT, Graphormer)
Perform similarity searching and virtual screening
limitations: Requires installing molfeat Python package separately
Some featurizers need optional dependencies (transformer, dgl, graphormer)
Deep learning models require GPU for optimal performance
3D descriptors require conformer generation which is computationally expensive

use_cases.title: Build QSAR prediction models
use_cases.description: Train machine learning models to predict molecular properties like solubility, toxicity, or activity from chemical structures.

use_cases.title: Screen compound libraries
use_cases.description: Rank large databases of compounds for biological activity using trained classifiers and similarity searching.

use_cases.title: Create molecular embeddings
use_cases.description: Generate numerical representations of molecules for downstream machine learning tasks using fingerprints and deep learning models.

best_practices: Use n_jobs=-1 for parallel featurization of large datasets
Save transformer configurations with to_state_yaml_file for reproducibility
Start with ECFP fingerprints for general-purpose machine learning tasks
Set ignore_errors=True when processing datasets with potentially invalid SMILES
anti_patterns: Processing one molecule at a time instead of batching
Using deep learning models for simple similarity searching tasks
Ignoring memory constraints when featurizing large compound libraries
Not caching expensive pretrained model embeddings for reuse

faq.question: Which featurizer should I start with?
faq.answer: ECFP (Extended-Connectivity Fingerprints) is the most popular choice for general-purpose tasks due to its speed and effectiveness.

faq.question: What is the difference between fingerprints and descriptors?
faq.answer: Fingerprints encode substructure presence as binary vectors. Descriptors calculate physicochemical properties as continuous values.

faq.question: Can molfeat be used with PyTorch or TensorFlow?
faq.answer: Yes, molfeat outputs numpy arrays that can be converted to torch tensors for deep learning frameworks.

faq.question: Does this skill install the molfeat library?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides documentation. Install molfeat separately with: uv pip install molfeat

faq.question: How many molecules can molfeat process efficiently?
faq.answer: With parallelization (n_jobs=-1) and chunked processing, molfeat can handle datasets with millions of molecules.

faq.question: What pretrained models are available?
faq.answer: ChemBERTa variants (77M-1.2B parameters), ChemGPT, GIN graph models, and Graphormer for quantum chemistry.
